TOMORROW our film INHERITANCE (@inheritance_thefilm) will have a second showing at Slamdance Film Festival in Park City, Utah.

INHERITANCE tells the story of an often overlooked America and a family caught in the grips of intergenerational trauma and addiction. Filmed over 11 years in one Appalachian town the film follows a boy as he grows up from age 12 to 18 surrounded by chaos, addiction and powerful love.

We want the film to fuel conversations, provide space for empathy and break stigmas around substance abuse and mental health.

We are so appreciative to our Editor Curtis Whitear (@curtiswhitear), our Composer Kyle Scott Wilson (@kyle_scott_wilson) and our Executive Producers Morgan Pehme and Daniel DiMauro (@dan__dimauro), Sam Cullman, Erik (@e1heyer) and Leslie Heyer, and Dave A. Liu (@liucrative). 

If you would like to support our film:

JOIN US: at Slamdance! INHERITANCE is in competition for a Grand Jury Award so please come out and support us! 

FOLLOW US: keep apprised of our future showings, sign up for our email list on our website (www.inheritancethefilm.com) and follow us here on Instagram @inheritance_thefilm

SHARE: spread the word and share this post and our mission. Let’s build a more compassionate world, one story at a time

SCREENING INFORMATION:
Slamdance Film Festival in Park City, Utah
Tuesday, Jan. 23rd, 2024 at 9:15 p.m. MST at The Yarrow - Theater B

Tickets can be purchased at the link in our bio. 

For viewers interested in the virtual showings, please visit slamdancechannel.com, or the link in our bio under “VIRTUAL TICKET.”

Score by @kyle_scott_wilson

We are excited to announce the PREMIERE of our feature-length documentary film “INHERITANCE” at Slamdance Film Festival in Park City, Utah this month. 

Over a decade in the making, @inheritance_thefilm follows one boy’s journey into adulthood surrounded by addiction, poverty and powerful love. 

To join us in-person or virtually for the PREMIERE of INHERITANCE, follow the link in our bio!

I have always prioritized the content of my work over the tools I use. Don't get me wrong – gear is important - but it’s not what fuels me. I need my equipment to be really good on so many levels, including that it helps celebrate the story I am working to tell.⁠
⁠
A few years ago I needed a computer screen and I asked my friend @aboutrc (who is really smart about gear) what to get and he introduced me to the folks at BenQ. They sent me a screen to try and from then on I’ve been hooked. I’m proud to say I have since become an official ambassador! ⁠Thankful for a screen that reflects and celebrates what I saw. 
⁠
image 01: Australia⁠
image 02: The Northern Forest Canoe Trail in ADK, New York⁠
Image 03: Ashram in India⁠
Image 04: my awesome BenQ screen⁠
⁠
@aqcolor_by_benq @benqnorthamerica⁠
⁠
#BenQ #AQCOLOR #SW272U #BenQAmbassador #Monitors #PhotoEditing ⁠

FROM MY ARCHIVE | Monhegan Island Post 05 (final):: I got my start at @natgeo in 1999 as a photo intern when I did my first story for the magazine. I was asked if I had an idea for a project and I proposed Monhegan – a small island 10 miles off the coast of Maine. I am from New England and had lived on the Maine coast as a young adult. I had always been curious about the 2 mile long and ½ mile wide island. In the summers the place overflows with tourists, but the year round population is only about 60-70. The islanders’ de facto fishing territory became the Monhegan Lobster Conservation Area in 1996 with a limited season starting in October. The island’s windswept landscape, quirky community and the dramatic cliffs have inspired artists like Robert Henri, George Bellows, Rockwell Kent, Edward Hopper, Lynn Mapp Drexler and three generations of the Wyeth family to name a few. ⁠
⁠
The community took me in and sometimes chewed me up. My time and experiences there changed and shaped my life in profound and beautiful ways that continue to impact me almost 25 years later; working with photo editor Susan Welchman who took me under her wing and has been my mentor and dear friend since and within days of arriving to the island, I also met one of my best friends @tralice_pooltoyphotos ⁠
⁠
Image 01 ⁠
Morning fog lifts off the meadow behind the Josiah Starling house, the oldest house on the island, built in 1784.⁠
⁠
Image 02⁠
The island gardener works on the flower beds around the Island Inn.⁠
⁠
Image 03⁠
Lobsterman Bryan Hitchcock⁠
⁠
Image 04⁠
Tulips in the moonlight⁠
⁠
#maine #monheganisland #nationalgeographic #natgeo #newengland #lobster #conservation #lobstermen #monhegan #landtrust #atlanticocean ⁠#flowers #meadow #tulips⁠

FROM MY ARCHIVE | Monhegan Island Post 04 :: I got my start at @natgeo in 1999 as a photo intern when I did my first story for the magazine. I was asked if I had an idea for a project and I proposed Monhegan – a small island 10 miles off the coast of Maine. I am from New England and had lived on the Maine coast as a young adult. I had always been curious about the 2 mile long and ½ mile wide island. In the summers the place overflows with tourists, but the year round population is only about 60-70. The islanders’ de facto fishing territory became the Monhegan Lobster Conservation Area in 1996 with a limited season starting in October. The island’s windswept landscape, quirky community and the dramatic cliffs have inspired artists like Robert Henri, George Bellows, Rockwell Kent, Edward Hopper, Lynn Mapp Drexler and three generations of the Wyeth family to name a few. ⁠
⁠
The community took me in and sometimes chewed me up. My time and experiences there changed and shaped my life in profound and beautiful ways that continue to impact me almost 25 years later; working with photo editor Susan Welchman who took me under her wing and has been my mentor and dear friend since and within days of arriving to the island, I also met one of my best friends @tralice_pooltoyphotos ⁠
⁠
Image 01 ⁠
Winnie Murdock and her son Kyle spend the fifty-minute boat ride from Port Clyde to Monhegan Island napping and reading Harry Potter while Winnie's husband John drives them home.⁠
⁠
Image 02⁠
Lobster bait arrives on the dock. Lobstermen on Monhegan use a mix of mackerel and herring to lure the lobsters into their traps. ⁠
⁠
Image 03⁠
The Laura B. ferryboat finishes the 10 mile, one hour journey from the mainland to Monhegan Island, Maine. The Laura B, is one of several boats that services the island in the summer, but the only boat that runs year round. Islanders depend on the Laura B for food, mail, supplies and transportation to and from the mainland. ⁠
⁠
Image 04⁠
A Monhegan Lobsterman pulls his skiff up Fish Beach at the end of a long day of fishing.⁠
⁠
#maine #monheganisland #nationalgeographic #natgeo #newengland #lobster #conservation #lobstermen #monhegan  #atlanticocean ⁠
